_header: When that April with his showers soot
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the General Prologue to the Canterbury Tales — 858 lines in rhyming couplets

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Whan that Apprill with his shouris sooteThe drought of Marche hath
                    pershid to the roote…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…And he bigan with right a mery chereHis tale anoon &
                    seide as ye may here
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth the prolog of this book the which is namede the talis of
                    Caunturbury in the whiche prolog thauthour openly declarith the names of alle
                    the pilgremes there condiciouns & there array (f. 4); the prolog (RT); Here
                    endith the prolog of this book… (f. 15v)
BodArcSelB14.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BodBar20.First Lines:
…That swiche a lewed mannes witte shal paceThe wisdom of an
                    hepe of lerned men…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…And he by gan with riȝt a merie chereHis tale anoon and
                    seide as ȝe maye here
BodBar20.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

Bod414.First Lines:
Whan that April with his shouris soteThe drought of March hath
                    percid to þe Rote…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…And he began with right a mery chereHis tale anone and seid
                    as ye may here

Bod686.First Lines:
Whan that april with his showres swoteThe drouth of March hath
                    perced the rote…
Bod686.Last Lines:

                    as þe may here

BodDoud4.First Lines:
…Þat had bot lytell golde in coffreBut all þat he
                    myght of his frendys hente…
BodDoud4.Last Lines:
…But alle with siluer wrought full clene and wellTheire
                    girdelis and theire pouchis euerydeell…
BodDoud4.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BodHatDon1.First Lines:
Whan that Aprill with his showres swoteThe drought of Marche hath
                    perced þe rote…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…Now late vs ride and herkeneth what I sayAnd with that worde
                    we riden forth oure wey
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
Here beginneth the Prolog of the Tales of Caunterbury (f. 1); The Prolog
                    (RT)
BodHatDon1.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BodLauMis600.First Lines:
That in hir cuppe was no ferthing seeneOf grece whan she had drunke
                    hir drauhte…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…And he began with right amery chereHis tale anoon and seide
                    as ye mai here
BodLauMis600.Attributed Title:
þe prolog (RT); HEre endeth the prolog of this book… (f.
                        14v)
BodLauMis600.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BodLauMis739.First Lines:

                    had perced vn to rote…
BodLauMis739.Last Lines:
…And he byganne with ryȝt a mery ChereHis tale anon and
                    seid as ȝe may here

…Olde ypocras holy and galyeneSerapion rafi and
                    auysene…

                    we ryden forthe oure way

…ffor to telle ȝow of his arrayhis hors were goode but
                    he was not gay…

                    as ȝe may heere

OxfNew314.First Lines:
…fforto be wise in byinge of vitailffor wheþir he paide
                    or took be tailAlgate he waitid so on his acateThat he was ay before
                    & in good state…
OxfNew314.Last Lines:
…And he began with riȝt a mery chereAnd saide anone his
                    tale as ye shul here

OxfTri49.First Lines:
When that Aperil with his shouris swotethe drought of Marche hath
                    percid the rote…
OxfTri49.Last Lines:
…yif euen song and morw song acordelat se nowe ho schal telle
                    oure first tale

CULDd424.First Lines:
…[ffor] though a wydewe had nouȝt a shooSo plesant was
                    his In PrincipioȜet wold he haue a ferthyng or he wentHis purchas
                    was wel betir than his rent…
CULDd424.Last Lines:
…And he bygan with right a mery chereThis tale a non and seide
                    on þis manere
CULDd424.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

CULGg427.First Lines:
…Me thynketh it a cordaunt to resounTo telle ȝow al the
                        conchusyoun
condition…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Bold of hese speche & wis & wel I tauȝtAnd of
                    manhod hym lakkede ryȝt
                    natiȝtnoȝt…
CULGg427.Note:
I.1-36, 757-858 lost; 289 omitted with blank following 290. The addition
                    of ‘condition’ is by a later hand.
CULGg427.Facsimiles:
Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Poetical Works. Geoffrey Chaucer. A Facsimile of Cambridge University
                Library MS Gg.4.27. 3 vols Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1979 (vol. 1); 1980 (vols. 2-3).

Furnivall,  Frederick James.

CULIi326.First Lines:
…And euermore he hadde the souereyn prisAnd though that he
                    was war he was wise…
CULIi326.Last Lines:
…And he be gan with right a merye chereAnd seide anoone this
                    tale as ye shall here
CULIi326.Note:
I.1-66 lost; 191, 243-4, 297-8, 305, 334, 400, 403, 410 omitted; blank
                    lines left for 684 and 830 (subsequently added); 271-2, 517-18, 685-6
                    reversed.
CULIi326.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

CULMm25.First Lines:
…Syngynge he was or floytynge alle þe dayeHe was as
                    fresshe as is þe moneth of Maye…
CULMm25.Last Lines:
…Ande beganne with riȝt a mery cheereHis taale anon and
                    seide as ȝe may here
CULMm25.Attributed Title:
Prologus (RT); Here endith þe prologe of þis booke (f.
                    10)
CULMm25.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

CamFitzMc181.First Lines:
[W]Han that Aprile with his schoures sooteThe drouthe of marche
                    hathe persed þe rote…
CamFitzMc181.Last Lines:
…And bygan with ryght a mery chereHis tale anone and seyd as
                    ye may here
CamFitzMc181.Note:
I.243-6, 739-42, 794 omitted; 533-4, 657-8, 727, 792-3 reversed. In the
                        General Prologue, names of pilgrims occur as running titles, e.g.,
                    ‘A yeman’.
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Author:
Here bigynneth the Talys of Caunterbiry / Compiled by Geffrei Chaucers (f.
                    1)
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth the Talys of Caunterbiry / Compiled by Geffrei Chaucers (f.
                    1); Here endeth þe prolog of þis Boke… (f.
                    15v)
CamFitzMc181.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

CamTCC582.First Lines:
Whan that Aprille with his shoures sooteThe drouȝt of Marche
                    hath perced to the rooteAnd bathed eueri veyne in such licoureOf wich
                    vertu engendred is the floure…
CamTCC582.Last Lines:
…And he be gan right thus with a goodli cheerHis tale anon and
                    seid as ye may hiere
CamTCC582.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

CamTCC595.First Lines:
…In granade at the siege eke had he beIn algreth had he ryden
                    and in belmarye…
CamTCC595.Last Lines:
…And he began with right amery chiereAnd seyde anone his tale
                    as ye shalle here
CamTCC595.Note:
Begins I.56; lines 1-55 supplied by a later (sixteenth-century) hand on
                    ff. 3v-4v. 197-8, 221, 303, 400, 403 omitted; 543-71
                    follow 601 (f. 13 inverted); spurious lines added after 163, 165, 207, 308, 404;
                    517-18, 685-6 reversed.
CamTCC595.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BLAdd10340.First Lines:
Þere was a pore person of a touneAnd was a goode man of
                    religioune…
BLAdd10340.Last Lines:
…But cristes lore & hys apostles tweluehe tauȝt but
                    first he folwed it hym selue

Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

BLAdd35286.First Lines:

                    brood y trowe…
BLAdd35286.Last Lines:
…And he by ganne ryght wyth a mury cheereHis tale anon and
                    seyde as ye may heere

BLHar1758.First Lines:
Whan that Aprill with his schoures swoteThe drought of Marche hath
                    perced to þe rote…

                    sort or cas

BLHar7333.First Lines:
Whanne þat Aperyll with his shoures swooteÞe Drowght of
                    marche hathe perced to þe rote…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Þus he bygan with Right A goodly chereHis tale A noon
                    And sayde as ye may hereLoo here eondiþe þe prologe of þe
                    Knightes tale
BLHar7333.Attributed Title:
On f. 37, the poem is introduced as ‘The Prologue of the Knyghtes
                    Tale’, followed by the heading: ‘O yee so noble and worthi pryncis
                    and princesse oþer estatis or degrees. what euer yee beo þat haue
                    disposicione or plesaunce. to rede or here þe stories of olde tymis passed
                    to kepe yow frome ydelnesse and slowþe. in escheuing oþer folies
                    þat might be cause of more harome filowyng vowcheth sauf I be seche yowe.
                    to fynde yowe occupacioun in þe Reding here of þe tales of
                    Caunterburye wiche beon compilid in þis boke filowyng ffirst foundid
                    ymagenid and made boþe for disporte and leornyng of all þoo that beon
                    gentile of birthe or of condiciouns by þe laureal and moste famous poete
                    þat euer was to fore him as in þemvelisshing of oure rude moders
                    englisshe tonge. clepid Chaucyer a Gavfrede of whos soule god for his mercy have
                    pitee of his grace Amen;’; Nowe here firste begynnyþe þe prologe
                    of þe / kneytis tale (f. 33va; to introduce the General
                        Prologue)
BLHar7333.Editions:
Solopova,  Elizabeth,
                        ed.  
             The General Prologue on CD-ROM.
         Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000.

Petworth7.First Lines:
Whan that aprille with his shoures sooteThe drouht of marche hath
                    perced to þe roote…
Petworth7.Last Lines:
…And byganne wiþ riȝt amery chereHis tale anon and
                    seide as ȝe may hereIamque domos patrias Scithice post aspera
                        gentisPrelia laurigere & ceteraThus endeþ
                    þe prologe of þis bokeHere bygynneth the Knyghtes
                    tale
Petworth7.Editions:

Austin143.First Lines:
…Her mouthe full small and therto softe and redeBut sikirly
                    she had a faire forehede…

                    on this manere
